abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Population & AIDS
            Control Project is rated as satisfactory, sustainability as
            likely, institutional development impact as modest, Bank
            performance as satisfactory, and borrower performance as
            satisfactory. Several of the lessons learned from this
            project concern the lack of leadership commitment towards
            key basic objectives of the project, the need to clarify
            institutional arrangements during project design, and the
            importance of baseline data for proper project design and
            monitoring. There is a great need in Francophone sub-Saharan
            Africa for enhanced policy dialogue in population and
            reproductive health. And the policy dialogue needs to be
            focused. Task teams need to better recognize that results in
            the area of population, reproductive health, and
            HIV/AIDS/STDs take time to materialize in the SSA context
            because they involve tackling sensitive issues in
            traditional cultures. Monitoring and evaluation systems and
            baseline data are a priority, particularly in population and
            HIV/AIDS/STDs projects. The project demonstrated that even
            in highly traditional and religious cultures, it is possible
            to bring about social change through the use of good
            information, education, and communication messages and
            social marketing techniques, and to get the population to
            learn fairly rapidly about HIV/AIDS/STDs.
